RULE.name: Always override junit.framework.TestCase.suite() as a public static method
Avoid incorrect name format for TestSuite classes
Always call super.setUp() from JUnit TestCase's setUp() method
Always override 'tearDown()' method in a JUnit test case
Always override 'setUp()' method in a JUnit test case
Avoid incorrect name format for JUnit TestCase subclasses
Always call super.tearDown() from JUnit TestCase's tearDown() method
Avoid calling constructors to setup test cases
Avoid using Thread.dumpStack() in production code
Avoid profiling with java.lang.Runtime.freeMemory()
Avoid profiling with java.lang.Runtime.traceMethodCalls()
Avoid using java.lang.Throwable.printStackTrace() in production code
Avoid using System.out or System.err in production code
Avoid profiling with java.lang.Runtime.traceInstructions()
Avoid profiling with java.lang.Runtime.totalMemory()
Close open JDBC resources in finally() blocks
Avoid the throw statement inside of finally
Avoid calling finalize() except in the finally block of the finalize method
Avoid instantiating Strings using new
Avoid instantiating unnecessary temporaries when converting primitive types to java.lang.String
Avoid calling java.lang.Runtime.runFinalizersOnExit()
Avoid instantiating a Number using new
Avoid calling java.lang.Runtime.runFinalization()
Avoid declaring finalize() public
Avoid using static collections
Close open streams in finally() blocks
Avoid invoking Garbage Collection
Avoid returning from finally
Avoid instantiating Booleans using new
Reuse resources for JDBC connections
Use javax.sql.DataSource to open JDBC connections
Avoid java.lang.String + operator in loops
Close open JDBC connections in finally() blocks
Always call super.finalize() in the finally block of finalize() methods
Avoid creating empty JAR or ZIP file entries
Avoid synchronized blocks inside loops
Always instantiate collections with a specific size
Avoid checking the length of a String by invoking String.equals("")
Avoid using java.net.URL equals() and hashCode() methods
Avoid calling methods in conditions of for loops
Avoid declaring or assigning variables in a loop that are not dependent on the loop condition
Avoid unnecessary equality operations with booleans
Avoid try catch finally blocks inside loops
Avoid Map and Set of java.net.URL objects
Avoid creating a new object for the purpose of invoking getClass() on it
Avoid using java.lang.Class.forName()
Avoid multiple invocations of the same method
Avoid nesting more than 4 if statements
Avoid conditional expressions with 4 or more operators
Avoid nesting more than 3 loops
Avoid nesting more than 1 classes
Avoid nesting more than 1 try catch blocks
Avoid multiple overloaded methods with the same number of parameters

Avoid using java.lang.String + operator

Avoid invoking a static java.lang.Math method on a constant
Avoid invoking nextDouble() to generate a random int
Avoid casting an int value to double and then passing the value to Math.ceil()
Avoid casting an int value to float and then passing the value to Math.round()
Avoid computation of a variable with itself
Avoid casting the result of integer division to double
Avoid modulus values of one
Avoid confusing multiplication of int remainder by a constant int value
Avoid using var%2==1 to check if a variable is an odd value
Avoid calling toString() on String objects
Use StringBuffer instead of String for non-constant String objects
Use String instead of StringBuffer for constant String objects
Always use StringTokenizer for parsing instead of indexOf() or substring()
Avoid creating a primitive type using auto-boxing in order to call toString on it
Avoid checking if String.indexOf() is a positive value
Avoid calling toString() on an array
Avoid replacing '.' using the String replace methods
Always provide a Locale parameter
Avoid calling subString(0) on a string object
Avoid chaining assignment operators
Avoid creating a new class instance, in the class static initializer, before all static final fields are initialized
Avoid initialization of a superclass with its subclass
Always initialize static fields
Avoid changing the value of a method parameter
Avoid calling java.lang.Class.getDeclaredField()
Avoid calling java.lang.Class.getDeclaredMethod()
Avoid calling java.lang.Class.getMethod
Avoid calling java.lang.Class.getField()
Avoid empty finalize() method methods
Avoid overloading the finalize() methods
Avoid unnecessary finalize() methods
Avoid removing listeners inside finalize methods
Always call super.finalize()
Never invoke finalize() method
Avoid using text labels in 'switch' statements
Always provide the default label in switch statements
Always provide break at the end of every case statement
Avoid switch statements with few branches, use if else instead
Always invoke super.clone() from a clone()
Always declare clone() method public
Avoid implementing Cloneable without overriding clone()
Implement Cloneable interface when clone() is overridden
Avoid calling constructors in the clone() method
Always declare clone() with CloneNotSupportedException for Cloneable classes
Avoid declaring variables of basic and array types in the same statement
Avoid using explicit string literals, declare constants instead
Avoid declaring multiple variables in a single statement
Avoid using interfaces or abstract classes just to declare common constants
Avoid C-style syntax when declaring arrays
Avoid using java.awt.peer interfaces directly
Avoid returning null instead of Enumeration
Avoid returning null instead of Iterator
Avoid returning null instead of empty array
Avoid null assignments outside of a field/variable declaration
Avoid a return of a boolean variable as the only statement in an if/else
If/else statement can generate a NullPointerException
Avoid using if/else statements for short conditions
Avoid using assignments inside 'if' conditions
Avoid using negation in if else conditions
Avoid using "break" and "continue" with labels
Avoid hard coding \n and \r as line separators
Avoid implementing java.awt.peer.* interfaces
Avoid calling java.lang.System.getenv()
Avoid hard coding file separators when creating a java.io.File
Use for loops instead of while loops
Avoid a for loop without a condition
Avoid calling contains() inside a loop
Avoid using continue statements
Avoid re-using control variables in nested loops
Avoid using loops to copy arrays
Avoid a for loop without an initializer and an incrementor
Avoid assigning loop control variables in the body of for loops
Avoid method invocations in the loop condition statement
Avoid using Enumeration, use Iterator instead
Always provide an '@invariant' tag for all protected classes
Always provide JavaDoc comments for public classes and interfaces
Always provide JavaDoc comments for protected classes and interfaces
Always provide an '@invariant' tag for all public classes
Always provide JavaDoc comments for a toString() method
Always provide the @concurrency JavaDoc tag and a description for synchronized 'private' methods and blocks
Always provide an '@post' tag for all protected methods
Always provide the @return JavaDoc tag for public methods with a return type
Always provide @throws tag in the correct order for each exception thrown by a public method
Always provide an '@pre' tag for all public methods
Always provide an '@post' tag for all private methods
Always provide an '@pre' tag for all protected methods
Avoid TODO comments in production code
Always provide @throws tag in the correct order for each exception thrown by a protected method
Avoid placing non-JavaDoc comments in between JavaDoc and class/method declarations
Always provide the @concurrency JavaDoc tag and a description for synchronized 'package private' methods and blocks
Avoid using the @exception tag for exceptions thrown
Always provide JavaDoc comments for public methods
Always provide @param tags in the correct order for private methods
Always provide the @return JavaDoc tag for protected methods with a return type
Always provide JavaDoc comments for protected methods
Always provide @version tag for classes and interfaces
Always provide JavaDoc comments for public fields
Always provide JavaDoc comments for protected fields
Always provide an '@invariant' tag for all private classes
Always provide @param tags in the correct order for protected methods
Always provide an '@post' tag for all public methods
Always provide an '@pre' tag for all package private methods
Always provide @author tag for classes and interfaces
Always provide @param tag in the correct order or package private methods
Always provide an '@post' tag for all package private methods
Always provide the @concurrency JavaDoc tag and a description for synchronized 'protected' methods and blocks
Always provide an '@pre' tag for all private methods
Always provide a header block comment in each file
Always provide @throws tag in the correct order for each exception thrown by a package private method
Always provide the @return JavaDoc tag for package-private methods with a return type
Always provide an '@invariant' tag for all package private classes
Always provide @param tags in the correct order for public methods
Always provide @throws tag in the correct order for each exception thrown by a private method
Always provide the @return JavaDoc tag for private methods with a return type
Always provide the @concurrency JavaDoc tag and a description for synchronized 'public' methods and blocks

Avoid using 'Date[]', use 'long[]' instead

Avoid calling java.lang.Thread.run()

Avoid using synchronized modifier in method declaration

Avoid overriding a synchronized method with a non-synchronized one
Avoid extending java.lang.Thread

Avoid calling java.lang.Thread.yield()
Avoid calling java.lang.Thread.resume()
Avoid calling java.lang.Object.notifyAll() from non-synchronized blocks
Avoid/Enforce usage of "*" in import statements
Avoid using deprecated classes, interfaces, fields and methods
Avoid comparing float points
Avoid invoking "runFinalizerOnExit()"
Always use a constant String when invoking an SQL statement method with a String parameter
Avoid assigning a variable to itself
Avoid calling setSize() inside componentResized()
Avoid multiple returns in methods
Always write one statement per line
Avoid Unnecessary return statement at the end of void methods
Avoid empty if statements and empty loops
Avoid using labeled statements
Avoid adding a container to itself
Avoid assigning to a variable a value that it already has
Avoid immediately overriding an increment
Avoid invoking "System.exit()"
Always surround if and loop statements with curly braces
Avoid unnecessary instanceof() calls
Avoid calling this.getClass.getResource() from an extended class
Avoid passing a 0 as the index to a java.sql.ResultSet getter or update methods

Avoid using do-while statements
Avoid assigning a value to a local variable that is never used
Avoid empty switch statements
Avoid passing a 0 as the index to a java.sql.PreparedStatement setter method
Always check/use the return value of a method invocation
Avoid using objects to access static fields and methods
Avoid calling next() in hasNext()
Avoid using continue statements
Avoid declaring non-transient fields of non-serializable type inside of a serializable class
Always have a return type of java.lang.Object from readResolve() methods
Avoid declaring transient fields in non-serializable classes
Always declare a constructor for a class that implements java.io.Externalizable
Always declare readObject() and writeObject() as private in externalizable or serializable classes
Avoid passing an object that is not serializable to the method writeObect() in java.io.ObjectOutput
Always create a static final serialVersionUID field in serializable classes
Always declare readResolve() and writeReplace() as protected in externalizable or serializable classes
Avoid Non-Serializable classes with a Serializable inner class
Always implement java.io.Serializable if implementing java.lang.Comparable
Do not call non-"final", non-"static", non-"private" methods from constructors
Avoid reading from an uninitialized field in a constructor
Avoid calling an abstract method in a constructor in an abstract class
Avoid unnecessary constructors
Always provide 'private' constructors for a utility class
Do not declare 'public' constructors in non-public classes
Avoid calling an overridable method in a constructor
Declare only 'private' constructors for a utility class
Declare only 'protected' constructors in abstract classes

Avoid throwing many exceptions within the same method
